Federated Learning of a Mixture of Global and Local Models

Filip Hanzely King Abdullah University of Science and Technology
Thuwal, Saudi Arabia Peter RichtÃ¡rik King Abdullah University of Science and Technology
Thuwal, Saudi Arabia
(February 14, 2020)
Abstract

We propose a new optimization formulation for training federated learning models. The standard formulation has the form of an empirical risk minimization problem constructed to find a single global model trained from the private data stored across all participating devices. In contrast, our formulation seeks an explicit trade-off between this traditional global model and the local models, which can be learned by each device from its own private data without any communication. Further, we develop several efficient variants of SGD (with and without partial participation and with and without variance reduction) for solving the new formulation and prove communication complexity guarantees. Notably, our methods are similar but not identical to federated averaging / local SGD, thus shedding some light on the role of local steps in federated learning. In particular, we are the first to i) show that local steps can improve communication for problems with heterogeneous data, and ii) point out that personalization yields reduced communication complexity.

1 Introduction

With the proliferation of mobile phones, wearable devices, tablets, and smart home devices comes an increase in the volume of data captured and stored on them. This data contains a wealth of potentially useful information to the owners of these devices, and more so if appropriate machine learning models could be trained on the heterogeneous data stored across the network of such devices. The traditional approach involves moving the relevant data to a data center where centralized machine learning techniques can be efficiently appliedÂ (Dean etÂ al., 2012; Reddi etÂ al., 2016). However, this approach is not without issues. First, many device users are increasingly sensitive to privacy concerns and prefer their data to never leave their devices. Second, moving data from their place of origin to a centralized location is very inefficient in terms of energy and time.

1.1 Federated learning

Federated learning (FL) (McMahan etÂ al., 2016; KoneÄnÃ½ etÂ al., 2016b, a; McMahan etÂ al., 2017) has emerged as an interdisciplinary field focused on addressing these issues by training machine learning models directly on edge devices. The currently prevalent paradigmÂ (Li etÂ al., 2019; Kairouz etÂ al., 2019) casts supervised FL as an empirical risk minimization problem of the form

minxâˆˆâ„dâ¡1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nfiâ€‹(x),subscriptğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥\min\limits_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(x), (1)

where nğ‘›n is the number of devices participating in training, xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} encodes the dğ‘‘d parameters of a global model (e.g., weights of a neural network) and

fiâ€‹(x)â‰”ğ”¼Î¾âˆ¼ğ’Ÿiâ€‹[fâ€‹(x,Î¾)]â‰”subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ”¼similar-toğœ‰subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğœ‰f_{i}(x)\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{\xi\sim{\cal D}_{i}}\left[f(x,\xi)\right]

represents the aggregate loss of model xğ‘¥x on the local data represented by distribution ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–{\cal D}_{i} stored on device iğ‘–i. One of the defining characteristics of FL is that the data distributions ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–{\cal D}_{i} may possess very different properties across the devices. Hence, any potential FL method is explicitly required to be able to work under the heterogeneous data setting.

The most popular method for solving (1) in the context of FL is the FedAvg algorithmÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2016). In its most simple form, when one does not employ partial participation, model compression, or stochastic approximation, FedAvg reduces to Local Gradient Descent (LGD)Â (Khaled etÂ al., 2019, 2020), which is an extension of GD performing more than a single gradient step on each device before aggregation. FedAvg has been shown to work well empirically, particularly for non-convex problems, but comes with poor convergence guarantees compared to the non-local counterparts when data are heterogeneous.

1.2 Some issues with current approaches to FL

The first motivation for our research comes from the appreciation that data heterogeneity does not merely present challenges to the design of new provably efficient training methods for solving (1), but also inevitably raises questions about the utility of such a global solution to individual users. Indeed, a global model trained across all the data from all devices might be so removed from the typical data and usage patterns experienced by an individual user as to render it virtually useless. This issue has been observed before, and various approaches have been proposed to address it. For instance, the MOCHA (Smith etÂ al., 2017) framework uses a multi-task learning approach to allow for personalization. Next, (Khodak etÂ al., 2019) propose a generic online algorithm for gradient-based parameter-transfer meta-learning and demonstrate improved practical performance over FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). Approaches based on variational inferenceÂ (Corinzia & Buhmann, 2019), cyclic patterns in practical FL data sampling (Eichner etÂ al., 2019) transfer learning (Zhao etÂ al., 2018) and explicit model mixingÂ (Peterson etÂ al., 2019) have been proposed.

The second motivation for our work is the realization that even very simple variants of FedAvg, such as LGD, which should be easier to analyze, fail to provide theoretical improvements in communication complexity over their non-local cousins, in this case, GD (Khaled etÂ al., 2019, 2020).111After our paper was completed, a lower bound on the performance of local SGD was presented that is worse than the known minibatch SGD guaranteeÂ (Woodworth etÂ al., 2020a), confirming that the local methods do not outperform their non-local counterparts in the heterogeneous setup. Similarly, the benefit of local methods in the non-heterogeneous scenario was questioned inÂ (Woodworth etÂ al., 2020b).

This observation is at odds with the practical success of local methods in FL. This leads us to ask the question:

If LGD does not theoretically improve upon GD as a solver for the traditional global problemÂ (1), perhaps LGD should not be seen as a method for solvingÂ (1) at all. In such a case, what problem does LGD solve?

A good answer to this question would shed light on the workings of LGD, and by analogy, on the role local steps play in more elaborate FL methods such as local SGDÂ (Stich, 2020; Khaled etÂ al., 2020) and FedAvg.

2 Contributions

In our work we argue that the two motivations mentioned in the introduction point in the same direction, i.e., we show that a single solution can be devised addressing both problems at the same time. Our main contributions are:

â‹„â‹„\diamond New formulation of FL which seeks an implicit mixture of global and local models. We propose a new optimization formulation of FL. Instead of learning a single global model by solving (1), we propose to learn a mixture of the global model and the purely local models which can be trained by each device iğ‘–i using its data ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–{\cal D}_{i} only. Our formulation (see Sec.Â 3) lifts the problem from â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d} to â„nâ€‹dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{nd}, allowing each device iğ‘–i to learn a personalized model xiâˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. These personalized models are encouraged to not depart too much from their mean by the inclusion of a quadratic penalty Ïˆğœ“\psi multiplied by a parameter Î»â‰¥0ğœ†0\lambda\geq 0. Admittedly, the idea of softly-enforced similarity of the local models was already introduced in the domain of the multi-task relationship learningÂ (Zhang & Yeung, 2010; Liu etÂ al., 2017; Wang etÂ al., 2018) and distributed optimizationÂ (Lan etÂ al., 2018; Gorbunov etÂ al., 2019; Zhang etÂ al., 2015). The mixture objective we propose (seeÂ (2)) is a special case of their setup, which justifies our approach from the modeling perspective. Note thatÂ Zhang etÂ al. (2015); Liu etÂ al. (2017); Wang etÂ al. (2018) provide efficient algorithms to solve the mixture objective already. However, none of the mentioned papers consider the FL application, nor they shed a light on the communication complexity of LGD algorithms, which we do in our work.

â‹„â‹„\diamond Theoretical properties of the new formulation. We study the properties of the optimal solution of our formulation, thus developing an algorithmic-free theory. When the penalty parameter is set to zero, then obviously, each device is allowed to train their own model without any dependence on the data stored on other devices. Such purely local models are rarely useful. We prove that the optimal local models converge to the traditional global model characterized by (1) at the rate ğ’ªâ€‹(1/Î»)ğ’ª1ğœ†{\cal O}(1/\lambda). We also show that the total loss evaluated at the local models is never higher than the total loss evaluated at the global model (see Thm.Â 3.1). Moreover, we prove an insightful structural result for the optimal local models: the optimal model learned by device iğ‘–i arises by subtracting the gradient of the loss function stored on that device evaluated at the same point (i.e., a local model) from the average of the optimal local models (see Thm.Â 3.2). As a byproduct, this theoretical result sheds new light on the key update step in the model agnostic meta-learning (MAML) methodÂ (Finn etÂ al., 2017), which has a similar but subtly different structure.222The connection of FL and multi-task meta learning is discussed inÂ (Kairouz etÂ al., 2019), for example. The subtle difference is that the MAML update obtains the local model by subtracting the gradient evaluated at the global model. While MAML was originally proposed as a heuristic, we provide rigorous theoretical guarantees.

â‹„â‹„\diamond Loopless LGD: non-uniform SGD applied to our formulation. We then propose a randomized gradient-based methodâ€”Loopless Local Gradient Descent (L2GD)â€”for solving our new formulation (AlgorithmÂ 1). This method is, in fact, a non-standard application of SGD to our problem, and can be seen as an instance of SGD with non-uniform sampling applied to the problem of minimizing the sum of two convex functionsÂ (Zhao & Zhang, 2015; Gower etÂ al., 2019): the average loss, and the penalty. When the loss function is selected by the randomness in our SGD method, the stochastic gradient step can be interpreted as the execution of a single local GD step on each device. Since we set the probability of the loss being sampled to be high, this step is typically repeated multiple times, resulting in multiple local GD steps. In contrast to standard LGD, the number of local steps is not fixed, but random, and follows a geometric distribution. This mechanism is similar in spirit to how the recently proposed loopless variants of SVRG (Hofmann etÂ al., 2015; Kovalev etÂ al., 2020) work in comparison with the original SVRGÂ (Johnson & Zhang, 2013; Xiao & Zhang, 2014). Once the penalty is sampled by our method, the resultant SGD step can be interpreted as the execution of an aggregation step. In contrast with standard aggregation, which performs full averaging of the local models, our method merely takes a step towards averaging. However, the step is relatively large. We stress that the difference in terms of the algorithm statement between L2GD and LGD is rather minor as the main essence of these methods is identical. The key difference lies in the problem that the algorithms are employed to solve, and the resulting communication complexity.

â‹„â‹„\diamond Convergence theory. By adapting the general theory from (Gower etÂ al., 2019) to our setting, we obtain theoretical convergence guarantees assuming that each fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} is Lğ¿L-smooth and Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex (see Thm.Â 4.5). Interestingly, by optimizing the probability of sampling the penalty (we get pâ‹†=Î»Î»+Lsuperscriptğ‘â‹†ğœ†ğœ†ğ¿p^{\star}=\tfrac{\lambda}{\lambda+L}), which is an indirect way of fixing the expected number of local steps to 1+LÎ»1ğ¿ğœ†1+\tfrac{L}{\lambda}, we prove an

2â€‹Î»Î»+Lâ€‹LÎ¼â€‹logâ¡1Îµ2ğœ†ğœ†ğ¿ğ¿ğœ‡1ğœ€\tfrac{2\lambda}{\lambda+L}\tfrac{L}{\mu}\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}

bound on the expected number of communication rounds (see Cor.Â 4.6). We believe that this is remarkable in several ways. By choosing Î»ğœ†\lambda small, we tilt our goal towards pure local models: the number of communication rounds is tending to 0 as Î»â†’0â†’ğœ†0\lambda\to 0. If Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty, the solution our formulation converges to is the optimal global model, and L2GD obtains the communication bound ğ’ªâ€‹(LÎ¼â€‹logâ¡1Îµ)ğ’ªğ¿ğœ‡1ğœ€{\cal O}\left(\tfrac{L}{\mu}\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\right), which matches the efficiency of GD.

â‹„â‹„\diamond Personalization, local steps and communication complexity. Indeed, to the best of our knowledge, there is no result in the literature showing that local SGD communicates less than SGD on the classical FLÂ (1) with heterogeneous data. We are the first to show that (variants of) local SGD can outperform (synchronous) minibatch SGD in communication complexity if no data similarity is assumed.333Admittedly, local steps can reduce the communication complexity when some measure of data dissimilarity is bounded. However, data homogeneity assumptions are highly contentious in FL applications. However, as we argue in the next point, this happens with a twist: local methods need to be seen as algorithms for solving our personalized FL objective instead. Consequently, we are also the first to show that personalized FL444While we show it only for a particular personalized FL objective, we suspect that such a phenomenon applies to other personalized FL objectives too. can be easier to solve, in terms of communication complexity, compared to the traditional FL objectiveÂ (1).

â‹„â‹„\diamond What problem do local methods solve? Noting that L2GD is a (mildly nonstandard) version of LGD,555To be specific, L2GD is equivalent to Overlap LGDÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2020) with random local loop size. which is a key method most local methods for FL are based on, and noting that, as we show, L2GD solves our new formulation of FL, we offer a new and surprising interpretation of the role of local steps in FL. As mentioned, the role of local steps in the classical FL formulationÂ (1) with heterogeneous data is not to reduce the communication complexity. Instead, their role is to steer the method towards finding a mixture of the traditional global and the purely local models. Given that the stepsize is fixed, the more local steps are taken, the more we bias the method towards the purely local models. Our new optimization formulation of FL formalizes this as it defines the problem that local methods, in this case L2GD, solve. There is an added benefit here: the more we want our formulation to be biased towards purely local models (i.e., the smaller the penalty parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda is), the more local steps does L2GD take, and the better the total communication complexity of L2GD becomes. Hence, despite a lot of research on this topic, our paper provides the first proof that a local method (e.g., L2GD) can be better than its non-local counterpart (e.g., GD) in terms of total communication complexity in the heterogeneous data setting. We are able to do this by noting that local methods should better be seen as methods for solving the new FL formulation proposed here.

â‹„â‹„\diamond Generalizations: partial participation, local SGD and variance reduction. We further generalize and improve our method by allowing for (i) stochastic partial participation of devices in each communication round,(ii) subsampling on each device which means we can perform local SGD steps instead of local GD steps, and (iii) total variance reduction mechanism to tackle the variance coming from three sources: locality of the updates induced by non-uniform sampling (already present in L2GD), partial participation and local subsampling. Due to its level of generality, this method, which we call L2SGD++, is presented in the Appendix only, alongside the associated complexity results. In the main body of this paper, we instead present a simplified version thereof, which we call L2SGD+ (AlgorithmÂ 2). The convergence theory for it is presented in Thm.Â 5.1 and Cor.Â 5.2.

â‹„â‹„\diamond Heterogeneous data. All our methods and convergence results allow for fully heterogeneous data and do not depend on any assumptions on data similarity across the devices.

â‹„â‹„\diamond Superior empirical performance. We show through ample numerical experiments that our theoretical predictions can be observed in practice.

4 L2GD: Loopless Local GD

In this section we describe a new randomized method for solving the formulation (2). Our method is a non-uniform SGD for (2) seen as a 2-sum problem, sampling either âˆ‡fâˆ‡ğ‘“\nabla f or âˆ‡Ïˆâˆ‡ğœ“\nabla\psi to estimate âˆ‡Fâˆ‡ğ¹\nabla F. Letting 0<p<10ğ‘10<p<1, we define a stochastic gradient of Fğ¹F at xâˆˆâ„nâ€‹dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{nd} as follows

Gâ€‹(x)â‰”{âˆ‡fâ€‹(x)1âˆ’pwith probability1âˆ’pÎ»â€‹âˆ‡Ïˆâ€‹(x)pwith probabilityp.â‰”ğºğ‘¥casesâˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¥1ğ‘with probability1ğ‘ğœ†âˆ‡ğœ“ğ‘¥ğ‘with probabilityğ‘G(x)\coloneqq\begin{cases}\tfrac{\nabla f(x)}{1-p}&\text{with probability}\quad 1-p\\ \tfrac{\lambda\nabla\psi(x)}{p}&\text{with probability}\quad p\end{cases}. (7)

Clearly, Gâ€‹(x)ğºğ‘¥G(x) is an unbiased estimator of âˆ‡Fâ€‹(x)âˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘¥\nabla F(x). This leads to the following method for minimizing Fğ¹F, which we call L2GD: xk+1=xkâˆ’Î±â€‹Gâ€‹(xk).superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ›¼ğºsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\alpha G(x^{k}). Plugging the formulas for âˆ‡fâ€‹(x)âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¥\nabla f(x) and âˆ‡Ïˆâ€‹(x)âˆ‡ğœ“ğ‘¥\nabla\psi(x) into (7), and writing the resulting method in a distributed manner, we arrive at AlgorithmÂ 1. In each iteration, a coin Î¾ğœ‰\xi is tossed and lands 111 with probability pğ‘p and 00 with probability 1âˆ’p1ğ‘1-p. If Î¾=0ğœ‰0\xi=0, all Devices perform one local GD step (8), and if Î¾=1ğœ‰1\xi=1, Master shifts each local model towards the average via (9). As we shall see in Sec.Â 4.3, our theory limits the value of the stepsize Î±ğ›¼\alpha, which has the effect that the ratio Î±â€‹Î»nâ€‹pğ›¼ğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘\tfrac{\alpha\lambda}{np} cannot exceed 1212\tfrac{1}{2}. Hence, (9) is a convex combination of xiksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜x_{i}^{k} and xÂ¯ksuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘˜\bar{x}^{k}.

Note that AlgorithmÂ 1 is only required to communicate when a two consecutive coin tosses land a different value (see the detailed explanation in Sec.Â 4.2 of the appendix). Consequently, the expected number of communication rounds in kğ‘˜k iterations of L2GD is pâ€‹(1âˆ’p)â€‹kğ‘1ğ‘ğ‘˜p(1-p)k.

Remark 4.1

Our algorithm statements do not take the data privacy into the consideration. While privacy is a very important aspect of FL; in this paper, we tackle different FL challenges and thus we ignore privacy issues. However, the proposed algorithms can be implemented in a private fashion as well using tricks that are used in the classical FL scenarioÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017).

4.1 The dynamics of local GD and averaging steps

Notice that the average of the local models does not change during an aggregation step. Indeed, xÂ¯k+1superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘˜1\bar{x}^{k+1} is equal to

1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nxik+1â€‹=(â€‹9â€‹)â€‹1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1n[(1âˆ’Î±â€‹Î»nâ€‹p)â€‹xik+Î±â€‹Î»nâ€‹pâ€‹xÂ¯k]=xÂ¯k.1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜1italic-(9italic-)1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›delimited-[]1ğ›¼ğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ›¼ğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘˜\tfrac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}^{k+1}\overset{\eqref{eq:buiufg98fb}}{=}\tfrac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\left[\left(1-\tfrac{\alpha\lambda}{np}\right)x^{k}_{i}+\tfrac{\alpha\lambda}{np}\bar{x}^{k}\right]=\bar{x}^{k}.

If several averaging steps take place in a sequence, the point a=xÂ¯kğ‘superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘˜a=\bar{x}^{k} in (9) remains unchanged, and each local model xiksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜x_{i}^{k} merely moves along the line joining the initial value of the local model at the start of the sequence and ağ‘a, with each step pushing xiksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜x_{i}^{k} closer to the average ağ‘a.

In summary, the more local GD steps are taken, the closer the local models get to the pure local models; and the more averaging steps are taken, the closer the local models get to their average value. The relative number of local GD vs.Â averaging steps is controlled by the parameter pğ‘p: the expected # of local GD steps is 1p1ğ‘\tfrac{1}{p}, and the expected number of consecutive aggregation steps is 11âˆ’p11ğ‘\tfrac{1}{1-p}.

4.2 Understanding communication of L2GD

Example 4.2

In order to better understand when communication takes place in AlgorithmÂ 1, consider the following possible sequence of coin tosses: 0,0,1,0,1,1,1,0.001011100,0,1,0,1,1,1,0. The first two coin tosses lead to two local GD steps (8) on all devices. The third coin toss lands 111, at which point all local models xiksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜x_{i}^{k} are communicated to the master, averaged to form xÂ¯ksuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘˜\bar{x}^{k}, and the step (9) towards averaging is taken. The fourth coin toss is 00, and at this point, the master communicates the updated local models back to the devices, which subsequently perform a single local GD step (8). Then come three consecutive coin tosses landing 111, which means that the local models are again communicated to the master, which performs three averaging steps (9). Finally, the eighth coin toss lands 00, which makes the master send the updated local models back to the devices, which subsequently perform a single local GD step.

This example illustrates that communication needs to take place whenever two consecutive coin tosses land a different value. If 00 is followed by a 111, all devices communicate to the master, and if 111 is followed by a 00, the master communicates back to the devices. It is standard to count each pair of communications, Deviceâ†’â†’\toMaster and the subsequent Masterâ†’â†’\toDevice, as a single communication round.

Lemma 4.3

The expected number of communication rounds in kğ‘˜k iterations of L2GD is pâ€‹(1âˆ’p)â€‹kğ‘1ğ‘ğ‘˜p(1-p)k.

Remark 4.4

As stressed in SectionÂ 2, L2GD differs from LGD only in terms of the random local loop length and partial averaging. These two differences are minor and keep the essence of the method intact. We only decided to consider L2GD over LGD for the sake of convenience: it allows us to generate local methods as special cases of (existing and novel variants of) SGD. The major novelty of our approach is applying local methods to solve the personalized FL objectiveÂ (1), which allows us to obtain better communication guarantees and justifies the role of local steps in the heterogeneous data regime.

We now present our convergence result for L2GD.

Hence, our communication complexity result interpolates between the communication complexity of GD for finding the global model and the zero communication complexity for finding the pure local models.

L2GD and full averaging.

Is there a setup such that conditions of Thm.Â 4.5 are satisfied and the aggregation updateÂ (9) is identical to full averaging? This is equivalent requiring 0<p<10ğ‘10<p<1 such that Î±â€‹Î»=nâ€‹pğ›¼ğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘\alpha\lambda=np. However, we have Î±â€‹Î»â‰¤Î»2â€‹â„’â‰¤nâ€‹pğ›¼ğœ†ğœ†2â„’ğ‘›ğ‘\alpha\lambda\leq\tfrac{\lambda}{2{\cal L}}\leq np, which means that full averaging is not supported by our theory.

5 Loopless Local SGD with Variance Reduction

As we have seen in Sec.Â 4.3, L2GD is a specific instance of SGD, thus only converges linearly to a neighborhood of the optimum. In this section, we resolve the mentioned issue by incorporating control variates to the stochastic gradientÂ (Johnson & Zhang, 2013; Defazio etÂ al., 2014). We go further: we assume that each local objective has a finite-sum structure and propose an algorithm, L2SGD+, which takes local stochastic gradient steps, while maintaining (global) linear convergence rate. As a consequence, L2SGD+ is the first local SGD with linear convergence.888We are aware that a linearly converging local SGD (with Î»=âˆğœ†\lambda=\infty) can be obtained as a particular instance of the decoupling methodÂ (Mishchenko & RichtÃ¡rik, 2019). Other variance reduced local SGD algorithmsÂ (Liang etÂ al., 2019; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2019; Wu etÂ al., 2019) do not achieve linear convergence. For convenience, we present variance reduced local GD (i.e., no local subsampling) in the Appendix.

Assumption 5.1

Assume that fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} has a finite-sum structure:

fiâ€‹(xi)=1mâ€‹âˆ‘j=1mfi,jâ€²â€‹(xi).subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â€²ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–f_{i}(x_{{i}})=\tfrac{1}{m}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{m}f^{\prime}_{i,j}(x_{{i}}).

Let fi,jâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â€²ğ‘–ğ‘—f^{\prime}_{i,j} be convex, Lâ€²superscriptğ¿â€²{L^{\prime}}-smooth while fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex (for each 1â‰¤jâ‰¤m,1â‰¤iâ‰¤nformulae-sequence1ğ‘—ğ‘š1ğ‘–ğ‘›1\leq j\leq m,1\leq{i}\leq{n}).

5.1 Algorithm

Denote ğŸâˆˆâ„m1superscriptâ„ğ‘š{\bf 1}\in\mathbb{R}^{m} to be vector of ones. We are now ready to state L2SGD+ as AlgorithmÂ 2.

L2SGD+ only communicates when a two consecutive coin tosses land a different value, thus, on average pâ€‹(1âˆ’p)â€‹kğ‘1ğ‘ğ‘˜p(1-p)k times per kğ‘˜k iterations. However, L2SGD+ requires communication of control variates ğ‰iâ€‹ğŸ,ğš¿isubscriptğ‰ğ‘–1subscriptğš¿ğ‘–{\bf J}_{i}{\bf 1},{\bf\Psi}_{i} as well â€“ each communication round is thus three times more expensive. In the Appendix, we provide an implementation of L2SGD+ that does not require the communication of ğ‰iâ€‹ğŸ,ğš¿isubscriptğ‰ğ‘–1subscriptğš¿ğ‘–{\bf J}_{i}{\bf 1},{\bf\Psi}_{i}.

5.2 Convergence theory

We are now ready to present a convergence rate of L2SGD+ (the algorithm, along with the efficient implementation is presented in AppendixÂ B.2).

Remark 5.3

L2SGD+ is the simplest local SGD method with variance reduction. In the Appendix, we present L2SGD++ which allows for 1) an arbitrary number of data points per client and arbitrary local subsampling, 2) partial participation of clients, and 3) local SVRG-like updates of control variates (thus better memory). Lastly, L2SGD++ exploits the complex smoothness structure of the local objectives, resulting in tighter rates.

6 Experiments

In this section, we numerically verify the theoretical claims from this paper. We only present a single experiment here, all remaining ones along with the missing details about the setup are in the Appendix. In particular, the Appendix includes two more experiments. The first one studies how pğ‘{p} (parameter determining the communication frequency) influences the convergence of L2SGD+. The second experiment aims to examine the effect of parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda on the convergence rate of L2SGD+. Both of these experiments confirm our theoretical findings

We consider logistic regression problem with LibSVM dataÂ (Chang & Lin, 2011). The data were normalized so that fi,jâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â€²ğ‘–ğ‘—f^{\prime}_{i,j} is 1-smooth for each jğ‘—j, while the local objectives are 10âˆ’4superscript10410^{-4}-strongly convex. In order to cover a range of possible scenarios, we have chosen a different number of clients for each dataset (see the Appendix). Lastly, the stepsize was always chosen according to Thm.Â 5.1.

We compare three different methods: L2SGD+, L2GD with local subsampling (L2SGD in the Appendix), and L2GD with local subsampling and control variates constructed for Ïˆğœ“\psi only (L2SGD2 in the Appendix; similar toÂ (Liang etÂ al., 2019)). We expect L2SGD+ to converge to the global optimum linearly, while both L2SGD and L2SGD2 to converge to certain neighborhood. Each method is applied to two objectives constructed by a different split of the data among the devices. For the homogeneous split, we randomly reshuffle the data. For heterogeneous split, we first sort the data based on the labels and then construct the local objectives according to the current order.

Fig.Â 3 demonstrates the importance of variance reduction â€“ it ensures a fast global convergence of L2SGD+, while the neighborhood is slightly smaller for L2SGD2 compared to L2SGD. As predicted, data heterogeneity does not affect the convergence speed of the proposed methods.

7 Possible Extensions

Our analysis of L2GD can be extended to cover smooth convex and non-convex loss functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} (we do not explore these directions). Further, our methods can be extended to a decentralized regime where the devices correspond to devices of a connected network, and communication is allowed along the edges of the graph only. This can be achieved by introducing an additional randomization over the penalty Ïˆğœ“\psi. Further, our approach can be accelerated in the sense of NesterovÂ (Nesterov, 2004) by adapting the a variant of KatyushaÂ (Allen-Zhu, 2017; Qian etÂ al., 2019a) to our setting, thus further reducing the number of communication rounds.

Appendix A Experimental Setup and Further ExperimentsÂ 

In all experiments in this paper, we consider a simple binary classification model â€“ logistic regression. In particular, suppose that device iğ‘–{i} owns data matrix ğ€iâˆˆâ„mÃ—dsubscriptğ€ğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ‘šğ‘‘{\bf A}_{{i}}\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times d} along with corresponding labels biâˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}msubscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscript11ğ‘šb_{{i}}\in\{-1,1\}^{m}. fiâ€‹(x)â‰”1mâ€‹âˆ‘j=1mfi,jâ€²â€‹(x)+Î¼2â€‹â€–xâ€–2,wherefiâ€‹m+jâ€²â€‹(x)=logâ¡(1+expâ¡((ğ€i)j,:â€‹xâ‹…bi)).formulae-sequenceâ‰”subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â€²ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¥ğœ‡2superscriptnormğ‘¥2wheresubscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â€²ğ‘–ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘¥1â‹…subscriptsubscriptğ€ğ‘–ğ‘—:ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘–f_{{i}}(x)\coloneqq\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^{m}f^{\prime}_{{i},j}(x)+\frac{\mu}{2}\|x\|^{2},\quad\text{where}\quad f^{\prime}_{{i}m+j}(x)=\log\left(1+\exp\left(({\bf A}_{{i}})_{j,:}x\cdot b_{{i}}\right)\right).

In each case, we consider the simplest locally stochastic algorithm. In particular, each dataset is evenly split among the clients, while the local stochastic method samples a single data point each iteration.

A.1 Comparison of the methods

In our first experiment, we verify two phenomena:

  • â€¢

    The effect of variance reduction on the convergence speed of local methods. We compare 3 different methods: local SGD with full variance reduction (AlgorithmÂ 2), shifted local SGD (AlgorithmÂ 7) and local SGD (AlgorithmÂ 6). Our theory predicts that a fully variance reduced algorithm converges to the global optimum linearly, while both shifted local SGD and local SGD converge to a neighborhood of the optimum. At the same time, the neighborhood should be smaller for shifted local SGD.

  • â€¢

    The claim that heterogeneity of the data does not influence the convergence rate. We consider two splits of the data heterogeneous and homogeneous. For the homogeneous split, we first randomly reshuffle the data and then construct the local objectives according to the current order (i.e., the first client owns the first mğ‘šm indices, etc.). For heterogeneous split, we first sort the data based on the labels and then construct the local objectives accordingly (thus achieving the worst-case heterogeneity). Note that the overall objective to solve is different in homogeneous and heterogeneous case â€“ we thus plot relative suboptimality of the objective (i.e., Fâ€‹(xk)âˆ’Fâ€‹(xâ‹†)Fâ€‹(x0)âˆ’Fâ€‹(xâ‹†)ğ¹superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ¹superscriptğ‘¥â‹†ğ¹superscriptğ‘¥0ğ¹superscriptğ‘¥â‹†\tfrac{F(x^{k})-F(x^{\star})}{F(x^{0})-F(x^{\star})}) to directly compare the convergence speed.

In each experiment, we choose p=0.1ğ‘0.1{p}=0.1 and Î»=19ğœ†19\lambda=\tfrac{1}{9} â€“ such choice mean that pğ‘{p} is very close to optimal. The other parameters (i.e., number of clients) are provided in TableÂ 1. Fig.Â 4 presents the result.

As expected, FigureÂ 4 clearly demonstrates the following:

  • â€¢

    Full variance reduction always converges to the global optima, methods with partial variance reduction only converge to a neighborhood of the optimum.

  • â€¢

    Partial variance reduction (i.e., shifting the local SGD) is better than not using control variates at all. Although the improvement in the performance is rather negligible.

  • â€¢

    Data heterogeneity does not affect the convergence speed of the proposed methods. Therefore, unlike standard local SGD, mixing the local and global models does not suffer the problems with heterogeneity.

A.2 Effect of pğ‘{p}

In the second experiment, we study the effect of pğ‘{p} on the convergence rate of variance reduced local SGD. Note that pğ‘{p} immediately influences the number of communication rounds â€“ on average, the clients take (pâˆ’1âˆ’1)superscriptğ‘11({p}^{-1}-1) local steps in between two consecutive rounds of communication (aggregation).

In SectionÂ 5, we argue that, it is optimal (in terms of the convergence rate) to choose pğ‘{p} of order pâ‹†â‰”Î»Lâ€²+Î»â‰”superscriptğ‘â‹†ğœ†superscriptğ¿â€²ğœ†{p}^{\star}\coloneqq\tfrac{\lambda}{{L^{\prime}}+\lambda}. FigureÂ 5 compares p=pâ‹†ğ‘superscriptğ‘â‹†{p}={p}^{\star} against other values of pğ‘{p} and confirms its optimality (in terms of optimizing the convergence rate).

While the slower convergence of AlgorithmÂ 2 with p<pâ‹†ğ‘superscriptğ‘â‹†{p}<{p}^{\star} is expected (i.e., communicating more frequently yields a faster convergence), slower convergence for p>pâ‹†ğ‘superscriptğ‘â‹†{p}>{p}^{\star} is rather surprising; in fact, it means that communicating less frequently yields faster convergence. This effect takes place due to the specific structure of problemÂ (12); it would be lost when enforcing x1=â‹¯=xnsubscriptğ‘¥1â‹¯subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x_{1}=\dots=x_{{n}} (corresponding to Î»=âˆğœ†\lambda=\infty).

In this experiment we study how different values of Î»ğœ†\lambda influence the convergence rate of AlgorithmÂ 2, given that everything else (i.e., pğ‘{p}) is fixed. Note that for each value of Î»ğœ†\lambda we get a different instance of problemÂ (12); thus the optimal solution is different as well. Remark B.3

While both AlgorithmÂ 3 and AlgorithmÂ 2 are a special case of SAGA, the practical version of variance reduced local SGD (presented in SectionÂ B.3) is not. In particular, we wish to run the SVRG-like method locally in order to avoid storing the full gradient table.111111SAGA does not require storing a full gradient table for problems with linear models by memorizing the residuals. However, in full generality, SVRG-like methods are preferable. Therefore, variance reduced local SGD that will be proposed in SectionÂ B.3 is neither a special case of SAGA nor a special case of SVRG (or a variant of SVRG). However, it is still a special case of a more general algorithm fromÂ (Hanzely & RichtÃ¡rik, 2019).

As mentioned, AlgorithmÂ 2 is a generalization of AlgorithmÂ 3 when the local subproblem is a finite sum. Note that AlgorithmÂ 3 constructs a control variates for both local subproblem and aggregation function Ïˆğœ“\psi and constructs corresponding unbiased gradient estimator. In contrast, AlgorithmÂ 2 constructs extra control variates within the local subproblem in order to reduce the variance of gradient estimator coming from the local subsampling.

B.2 L2SGD+: Algorithm and the efficient implementation

Here we present an efficient implementation of L2SGD+ as AlgorithmÂ 4 so that we do not have to communicate control variates. As a consequence, AlgorithmÂ 4 needs to communicate on average pâ€‹(1âˆ’p)â€‹kğ‘1ğ‘ğ‘˜p(1-p)k times per kğ‘˜k iterations, while each communication consists of sending only local models to the master and back.

Note that LSVRG-like replacement is preferrable in practice due to a better memory efficiency (one does not need to store the whole gradient table) for the models other than linear.

Remark B.6

AlgotihmÂ 3 is a special case of AlgorithmÂ 2 which is in turn special case of AlgorithmÂ 5. Similarly, TheoremÂ 3 is a special case of TheoremÂ 5.1 which is again special case of TheoremÂ B.4.

B.4 Local stochastic algorithms

In this section, we present two more algorithms â€“ Local SGD with partial variance reduction (AlgorithmÂ 7) and Local SGD without variance reduction (AlgorithmÂ 6). While AlgorithmÂ 6 uses no control variates at all (thus is essentially AlgorithmÂ 1 where local gradient descent steps are replaced with local SGD steps), AlgorithmÂ 7 constructs control variates for Ïˆğœ“\psi only, resulting in locally drifted SGD algorithm (with the constant drift between each consecutive rounds of communication). While we do not present the convergence rates of the methods here, we shall notice they can be easily obtained using the framework fromÂ (Gorbunov etÂ al., 2020).

C.9 Proof of TheoremsÂ 5.1,Â B.4, andÂ B.5

Note first that AlgorithmÂ 2 is a special case of AlgorithmÂ 5, and TheoremÂ 5.1 immediately follows from TheoremÂ B.4. Therefore it suffices to show TheoremsÂ B.4, andÂ B.5. In order to do so, we will cast AlgorithmÂ 5 as a special case of GJS fromÂ (Hanzely & RichtÃ¡rik, 2019). As a consequence, TheoremÂ B.4 will be a special cases of Theorem 5.2 fromÂ (Hanzely & RichtÃ¡rik, 2019).

C.9.1 GJS

In this section, we quickly summarize results fromÂ (Hanzely & RichtÃ¡rik, 2019), which we cast to sho convergence rate of AlgorithmÂ 2. GJSÂ (Hanzely & RichtÃ¡rik, 2019) is a method to solve regularized empirical risk minimization objective, i.e.,
